title: Appendix N - Terms and Abbreviations Unique to this Book

contents.caption: Table 14: Terms and Abbreviations Unique to this Book
rows: An items that follows the verb in a standard sentence - an actor, object or X.
The complement X which is a direction/goal in a sentence with a directional variant verb, for example, an AF(D) sentence.
duplication of the first syllable of the root
A group of one or more enclitcs after a single host.
Exclusive - signals learner to use exclusive forms of we/us.
A structure of the form: focus + linker + noun clause.
Enclitic particles that do not apply to the focus of a standard sentence (e.g. din/rin, lang and naman(contrast)).
Describes what complements may be used with a given verb. It is called out in parentheses after the focus acronym. For example, AF(I) represents an intransitive variant of an AF verb.
a set way of mapping certain forms (ang/ng/sa) to the certain complement (actor/object/X)
a root without stress or glottal stops
A word that an enclitic attaches itself after.
hour of day, for example, alas-singko in Tagalog or “five” in English
Inclusive - signals learner to use inclusive forms of we/us.
Respectful - signals learner to use po and plural personal pronouns.
Soft - signals learner to use nga.
A sentence of the form: verb + actor + object + X
A sentence in large text, with an equal sign and abbreviations, that summarizes a grammar point.
One of the complements in a standard sentence - an IO, cause, directional compliment, benefactor or reference.
